titleproper.value:
Guide to the Saretta G. Hicks papers on Lady Deborah Moody
                    <num>ARC.276</num>

author.value: Finding aid prepared by Liz Larson

creation.value:
This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit
                <date>2011-11-28T11:49-0500</date>

unittitle.value: Saretta G. Hicks papers on Lady Deborah Moody

extent.value: in three full manuscript boxes and one half manuscript box.

abstract.label: Abstract
abstract.value:
This collection consists of papers gathered and, in many cases, written by author Saretta G. Hicks during the period 1963 to 1965. The material includes her notes and research for an unfinished book about Lady Deborah Moody titled 
                <emph render="italic">Dangerous Woman: A Biography of Deborah, Lady Moody of Coney Island</emph>. Lady Moody is best known as the founder of the town of Gravesend in what was then New Amsterdam and later became a part of Brooklyn, N.Y. Of particular note is the inclusion of copies of original documents pertaining to Lady Moody's family history. There is also a four-page typed transcript of Gravesend town meeting records from 1656.

p.value: Identification of item, date (if known); Saretta G. Hicks papers on Lady Deborah Moody, ARC.276, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Historical Society.
Source and date of acquisition for accession 1978.170 are unknown. Accession 1980.003 was the gift of the estate of Saretta G. Hicks, 1980.

She settled in New Amsterdam (later New York City), but in 1645 led a group of English settlers to Long Island and established a colony at Gravesend, located at the southern tip of Long Island, an area somewhat sheltered from the Atlantic Ocean by the westernmost extension of Coney Island and the town of New Utrecht. The grant to Lady Moody and her supporters consisted of present-day Coney Island and all of Gravesend and Sheepshead Bay. Author Jacob Judd noted that Gravesend "was organized under a Dutch patent providing for freedom of worship and self-government and by the 1650s had become a well-known haven for persecuted Quakers." It was also the first grant of land in the New World to a female.

Accession number 1980.003 consists of Hicks' typewritten manuscript of the first three chapters of 
                <emph render="italic">Dangerous Woman: A Biography of Deborah, Lady Moody of Coney Island</emph> and outlines of the remaining chapters. The collection also contains newspaper and magazine clippings about various locations in Massachusetts, New York, and England, as well as four indexes. The first of these organizes information about significant people and events in Lady Moody's life. The second indexes major dates in the history of the Moody family. The third index presents information on Gravesend and includes a list of early settlers. The fourth indexes bibliographic sources.
